This command is
used to generate a

module configuration
file. This configuration file can be used each time a

module is loaded in order to pass data
to the
module self tests. The
module always verifies its
but optionally only needs to run the
’s once, at installation.

The generated
configuration file consists of:
- A
of the

module
file.
- A test status indicator.

This indicates if the Known
Answer Self Tests (

’s) have
successfully run.
- A

of the
status indicator.
- A control for conditional self tests errors.

By default if a continuous test
(e.g a key pair test) fails then the

module will enter an error state, and no services or
cryptographic algorithms will be able to be accessed after
this point. The default value of ’1’ will cause
the fips module error state to be entered. If the value is
’0’ then the module error state will not be
entered. Regardless of whether the error state is entered or
not, the current operation (e.g. key generation) will return
an error. The user is responsible for retrying the operation
if the module error state is not entered.

p._value:
- A control to indicate whether
run-time security checks are done.

_values:
This indicates if run-time
checks related to enforcement of security parameters such as
minimum security strength of keys and approved curve names
are used. The default value of ’1’ will perform
the checks. If the value is ’0’ the checks are
not performed and

compliance must be
done by procedures documented in the relevant Security
Policy.

This file is
described in
Filename of the

module to perform an integrity check on.
The path provided in the filename is used to load the module
when it is activated, and this overrides the environment
variable

p._value:
Filename to output the
configuration data to; the default is standard output.

_values:
Input filename to load
configuration data from. Must be used if the
option is specified.

p._value:
Verify that the input
configuration file contains the correct information.

Name of the provider inside the
configuration file. The default value is
"fips".

Name of the section inside the
configuration file. The default value is
"fips_sect".

_values:
Specifies the name of a
supported

algorithm which will be used.
The

mechanisms that are available will
depend on the options used when building OpenSSL. To see the
list of supported

’s use the
command "openssl list -mac-algorithms". The
default is
Passes options to the

algorithm. A comprehensive list of
controls can be found in the

implementation documentation. Common control strings used
for this command are:
Specifies the

key as an alphanumeric string (use if the
key contains printable characters only). The string length
must conform to any restrictions of the
algorithm. A key must be specified for every

algorithm. If no key is provided, the
default that was specified when OpenSSL was configured is
used.
Specifies the

key in hexadecimal form (two hex digits
per byte). The key length must conform to any restrictions
of the

algorithm. A key must be specified
for every

algorithm. If no key is
provided, the default that was specified when OpenSSL was
configured is used.
Used by

as
an alphanumeric string (use if the key contains printable
characters only). The string length must conform to any
restrictions of the

algorithm. To see the
list of supported digests, use the command "openssl
list -digest-commands". The default digest is

p._value:
Disable logging of the self
tests.

Configure the module to not
enter an error state if a conditional self test fails as
described above.

Configure the module to not
perform run-time security checks as described above.

_values:
Do not write the two fields
related to the "test status indicator" and "

status indicator" to the output
configuration file. Without these fields the self tests

will run each time the module is loaded.
This option could be used for cross compiling, since the
self tests need to run at least once on each target machine.
Once the self tests have run on the target machine the user
could possibly then add the 2 fields into the configuration
using some other mechanism.

Do not output pass/fail
messages. Implies

The corrupt options can be used
to test failure of one or more self tests by name. Either
option or both may be used to select the tests to corrupt.
Refer to the entries for
and
in

(7) for values
that can be used.
Test that a

provider can be loaded from the specified configuration
file. A previous call to this application needs to generate
the extra configuration data that is included by the base
"parent_config" configuration file. See

(5) for further information on how to set up a
provider section. All other options are ignored if
’-config’ is used.

Self tests
results are logged by default if the options
and

are not specified, or if either of the
options
or

are
used. If the base configuration file is set up to autoload
the fips module, then the fips module will be loaded and
self tested

the fipsinstall
application has a chance to set up its own self test
callback. As a result of this the self test output and the
options
and

will
be ignored. For normal usage the base configuration file
should use the default provider when generating the fips
configuration file.

Calculate the
mac of a
module
and run a
self test for the module, and save the
configuration file:

Verify that the
configuration file

contains the correct
info:

p._value:
Corrupt any
self tests which have the description "SHA1":

_values:
openssl
fipsinstall -module ./fips.so -out fips.cnf -provider_name
fips \
-corrupt_desc 'SHA1'

p._value:
Validate that
the fips module can be loaded from a base configuration
file:

_values:
export
OPENSSL_CONF_INCLUDE=<path of configuration files>
export OPENSSL_MODULES=<provider-path>
openssl fipsinstall -config' 'default.cnf'
